results.title: Brassed off
results.creator_credit: Mark Herman, Steve Abbot, Channel Four Films and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: The Grimethorpe Colliery Band doesn’t have much to play for these days with the shadow of the mine’s imminent closure looming over them. Danny (Pete Postlethwaite) doesn’t share this view, as band master he sees the band as the life blood of the community. His son has the opposite view, blaming the conservative Thatcher government for the community’s misfortune. The band receives a lift in spirits with the arrival of Gloria (Tara Fitzgerald), a fluglehorn player eager to join the band but unbeknown to them is also part of the “management” team making decisions about the mine. For Andy (Ewan McGregor), Gloria’s appearance sparks memories of their brief teenage romance. When the mine closes and Danny is placed into hospital, plans for competing in the National Championship are placed on hold. After a series of conflicts however the band discovers a way of venting their anger and telling their story as well as that of miners elsewhere. An enjoyable comedy with a serious message about economic policy and the mining community. Also starring Jim Carter, Phillip Jackson, Stephen Moore, Ken Colley and Peter Gunn.

results.title: The Full Monty
results.creator_credit: Peter Cattaneo, Uberto Pasolini and Redwave Productions
results.brief_description:
Robert Carlyle stars as Gaz in this irreverent comedy set in the middle-England working class town of Sheffield. He is a jobless steel worker who dreams up an outrageous scheme to pull himself and his mates out of the personal and financial doldrums of long term unemployment. After seeing the money and adulation lauded upon the male exotic dance team The Chippendales by the females of the town, he rounds up willing and reticent participants for a review to be named the Full Monty. They are a collection of pigeon-chested, pot-bellied, heavy drinking, pale, wrinkly middle-aged strippers with one solitary gimmick - it all comes off!
Cast also includes: Tom Wilkinson, Mark Addy

results.title: The People vs. Larry Flynt
results.creator_credit: Milos Forman, Janet Yang, Michael Hausman, Oliver Stone and Ixtlan
results.brief_description: This is the story of the rise and rise of a self-confessed “smut-peddler”, Larry Flynt (Woody Harrelson) and his wife Althea (Courtney Love) and his building of a publishing empire, of which “Hustler” magazine is the figurehead. Along the way Flynt gets dragged to court by several exponent of the religious right, intent on defending the “decent folks”. At every turn, Larry fights back, using a tactic of high antics and retreat behind the “First Amendment”. Courted by the Pentecostal movement and Ruth Carter (Jimmy’s sister) played by Donna Hannover, he finally converts, only to give his campaign for “free speech and porn for all” the overtones of a crusade. The true life story of Larry Flynt is rich in sex, drugs, making money - and an assassination attempt. Who is Larry Flynt: a hedonistic, obnoxious pornograph or or an unlikely freedom of speech campaigner whose ardour is only tamed by drug addiction, mental illness, and Althea’s failing health? This film won two Oscar nominations to Forman and Harrelson. Winner of Golden Bear, Berlin - 1997. Includes cameos by Larry Flynt, James Carville (former Clinton ‘91 campaing director) and Donna Hannover.

results.title: The Woman Suffers
results.creator_credit: Raymond Longford and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This 1918 Australian feature is one of the most significant surviving treasures of a silent film heritage which is now largely extinct. The story takes the concept of primitive justice - an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth - and extends it to a sister for a sister. Ralph Manton discovers that his sister Marjory has been seduced and demands to be told the name of the man. Faithful to her lover, she refuses, but later Ralph discovers his identity and confronts him. The tables are turned. Starring Australia’s first film star, Lottie Lyell, the film was a critical and commercial success and offered audiences more than just a melodrama. It questioned the social mores of the day and the double standards of morality in regard to the men as the seducers. Musical accompaniment is by members of the Canberra Symphony Orchestra, conducted by composer Donald Hollier.

creators_primary.name: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Uncivilised
results.brief_description: This is the story of Beatrice Lynn, a high society author, who heads into the wilds of northern Australia in search of an Aboriginal tribe ruled by a white king, Mara. Along the way she is kidnapped and taken through the bush, encountering pituri smugglers, and battling a killer before finally being sold to Mara. In the tradition of true melodramas a love conflict develops between the white chief and Beatrice and leads to an epic Chauvel finale. Filmed in North Queensland and Palm Island and featuring spectacular rainforest and river cinematography, director Chauvel made this film in an attempt to break into the American market. Censorship problems relating to nude swimming as well as violence were eventually overcome for the Australian release while a censored version was released on the overseas market.

results.title: Bandit Queen
results.creator_credit: Shekhar Kapur, Sundeep S Bedi, Film Four International and Kaleidoscope
results.brief_description: This movie tells the “true story” of Phoolan Devi, the Indian bandit queen who was arrested in the state of Uttar Pradesh in 1983 for kidnapping and murder and was freed in 1994 because of a change in government. As a young girl she questioned the caste restrictions around her, is married at 13 but leaves the village and her marriage in search of independence. As a young woman she is captivated by Vikram, a bandit gang member. His gang kidnaps and rapes her, Vikram kills the leader and assumes leadership with Devi. Vikram is eventually killed in a dispute over leadership after SriRam returns from prison. Initially Devi is driven by seeking vengeance over the death of her lover, but after being gang raped by SriRam in her own village she is seeking revenge for herself. This culminates in the Behmai Massacre of February 1981. Cast includes Seema Biswas, Nirmal Pandey and Govind Namdeo.

results.title: Compulsion
results.creator_credit: Richard Fleischer, Richard Zanuck, Cinema Scope Pictures and Darryl F. Zanuck
results.brief_description: Based on the true story of the Leopold-Loeb murder case, Orson Welles stars as lawyer Jonathan Wilk, whose defence against capital punishment saves the lives of two teenagers , Judd and Artie. The two homosexual teenagers were charged with murdering a young boy as an example of their intellectual superiority. Bradford Dillman and Dean Stockwell star as the two accused, one sadistic, the other submissive, in this dramatic character study based on newspaper reporter Meyer Levin’s bestseller.

results.title: Torment = Hets
results.brief_description: The storyline of this film, although simple and straightforward, reveals a beautifully observed and incise psychological drama, written by Ingmar Bergman when he was 26 years old. It is the tale of sadistic teacher in a cheerless and strict school who takes delight in exercising his reign of terror over his Latin classes. One evening as final examination time approaches, one of his students, Jan-Erik, goes to the aid of Bertha, the newsagents assistant who is drunk in the street. They become lovers, but Jan-Erik is aware of the presence of another man in her life who frightens her. He finds Bertha dead in her room and on finding the teacher in her hallway discovers he is the other man. The teacher is arrested, but is released when the cause of her death is revealed as heart failure coupled with malnutrition. Following a confrontation with the teacher in the headmasters study, Jan-Erik is expelled from school, but when the headmaster becomes aware of the teachers tyrannical methods, the boy is reinstated and the teacher punished for his crimes.

results.title: The Shop on High Street = Obchod na korze
results.creator_credit: Emar Klos, Jan Kadar, Ceskoslovensky Filmexport and Filmove Studio Barrandov
results.brief_description: The film is set during World War II in the ‘independent’ facist Slovak statelet. It concerns Tono Brtko (Jozef Kroner), a carpenter who is appointed “Aryan controller” of a button shop by his facist brother-in-law. The shop is owned by the Jewish Frau Lautmann (Ida Kaminska, doyenne of the Yiddish Theatre in Poland), who is not only elderly but deaf and short-sighted, and thinks that Tono is her new assistant. Through a mixture of weakness, vacillation and decency he fails to disabuse her, and a mutually beneficial relationship develops. Meanwhile, the fascist authorities have other plans for the town’s Jews. This is an extraordinarily effective picture of ‘everyday fascism’ in a small community, and although it revolves around a grim and tragic theme, it is played largely as a gentle comedy. Winner of the 1965 Academy Award for Best Foreign Film. Adapted from a novel by Ladislav Grosman. In Czech with English sub-titles.

results.title: Eyes without a face
results.brief_description: Pierre Brasseur plays a surgeon who adopts extreme measures in his attempts to restore his daughter’s face (Edith Scob), horribly disfigured in a car crash. His obsessive efforts require him and his loyal assistant (Alida Valli) to kidnap young women and graft their features onto his daughter. Director Georges Franju and cinematographer Eugen Shuftan transform the pulp horror material into an eerie and surreal Cocteau-like nightmare. Eyes Without a Face has been remade twice by Spanish director Jess Franco, first as ‘The Awful Dr. Orloff’ and later as Faceless. Described by Franju as ‘an anguish film’, this film contains some haunting images, none more striking than Scob’s tortured eyes staring out from her stark, white expressionless mask. Music by Maurice Jarre. Based on a novel by Jean Redon. Also known as ‘The Horror chamber of Dr. Faustus’. In French with English subtitles.

Eyes Without a Face has been remade twice by Spanish director Jess Franco, first as ‘The Awful Dr. Orloff’ and later as Faceless. Described by Franju as ‘an anguish film’, this film contains some haunting images, none more striking than Scob’s tortured eyes staring out from her stark, white expressionless mask. Music by Maurice Jarre. Based on a novel by Jean Redon. Also known as ‘The Horror chamber of Dr. Faustus’. In French with English subtitles.
description_for_label: Pierre Brasseur plays a surgeon who adopts extreme measures in his attempts to restore his daughter’s face (Edith Scob), horribly disfigured in a car crash. His obsessive efforts require him and his loyal assistant (Alida Valli) to kidnap young women and graft their features onto his daughter. Director Georges Franju and cinematographer Eugen Shuftan transform the pulp horror material into an eerie and surreal Cocteau-like nightmare. Eyes Without a Face has been remade twice by Spanish director Jess Franco, first as ‘The Awful Dr. Orloff’ and later as Faceless. Described by Franju as ‘an anguish film’, this film contains some haunting images, none more striking than Scob’s tortured eyes staring out from her stark, white expressionless mask. Music by Maurice Jarre. Based on a novel by Jean Redon. Also known as ‘The Horror chamber of Dr. Faustus’. In French with English subtitles.
